title: 108_hr3204
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Benjamin Franklin Commemorative Coin Act". Benjamin Franklin made significant contributions to the development of the nation in various fields, signed all organizational documents, printed official currency for several colonies, proposed methods for currency exchange, designed the first American coin, and popularized the phrase "A Penny Saved is A Penny Earned" during the American Revolution. Benjamin Franklin's contributions include designing the Great Seal of the United States, appearing on the One Dollar Bill, and being the only non-president on circulating currency before 1979. His portrait was on the half dollar from 1948-1963, symbolizing America's commitment to free enterprise. The Franklin Institute Science Museum in Philadelphia houses the first steam printing machine for coinage used by the United States Mint. In 1976, Franklin Hall at The Franklin Institute Science Museum in Philadelphia was designated the Official National Monument to Benjamin Franklin. The Franklin Institute and other Philadelphia cultural institutions collaborated in 2000 to plan international programs for Franklin's 300th birth anniversary in 2006. The Benjamin Franklin Tercentenary Act was passed by Congress in 2002 to create a panel of distinguished Americans in Philadelphia to recommend Tercentenary programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $1 silver coins with younger and older Franklin images on the obverse, each containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and be legal tender. The Congress recommends that $1 silver coins with Franklin images be minted at the United States Mint in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, as numismatic items. Design of coins. Design Requirements for Benjamin Franklin coins include $1 coins with images of him as a young and older man, symbolizing his roles as a patriot, statesman, and in developing early American currency. The Act specifies design requirements for new coins, including inscriptions of value, year, and patriotic phrases. Designs are chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2006, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority will end on December 31, 2006. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins issued under this Act will be sold at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Single coins or sets can be purchased. The sale of coins under this Act includes a $10 surcharge per coin, with all surcharges going to the Franklin Institute for the Benjamin Franklin Tercentenary Commission. The Institute is subject to audit requirements for the funds received. No surcharge can be included if it would exceed the annual limit of 2 commemorative coin programs. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual commemorative coin program limit.
